item.title: Surrounding-Aware Correlation Filter for UAV Tracking with Selective Spatial Regularization
item.description:
This paper corresponds to the research project I’ve done in Vision4Robotics Group.

Visual tracking means to estimate the trajectory of an arbitrary object in a video, given the bounding box of the object in the first frame. I reviewed the development of the state-of-the-art algorithms, and was soon attracted by the elegant mathematical formula and superlative performance of “Correlation Filter-based methods”. Although I quickly had a new idea, things did not go out smoothly as the framework I designed did not work at first. Nevertheless, I dived deep into the formulas for an answer. Through days of analysis, inside the matrices and vectors, I found an implicit incompatibility of two modules in my framework. After solving it, rich experiments on UAV tracking videos demonstrated the good tracking ability of my framework.

item.title: Chain Reaction
item.description: In 2018 Open-Source Hardware and Programming, I organized a mechanical experiment as the TA lead. This module consist of 5 electro-mechanical sub-modules. In this class, students need to assemble the mechanical parts of the module, and program an Arduino to control the motion of it. Every five modules could be connected in a row to guide the motion of an orb. You can find the demonstration video HERE.

item.title: Deep Learning Course
item.description:
The Deep Learning course in Tongji University (2019 FALL) contains the following contents: - Machine learning basics: Linear regression/classification, Logistic regression for multi-class Classification problems. - Artificial Neural Networks: Fully-Connected Neural Networks, Convolutional Neural Networks, Recurrent Neural Networks. - Applications of Deep Learning: Image Classification, Transfer Learning, Style Transfer, Object Detection, Segmentation, GAN

Assignments include: Linear Regression with Numpy Logistic Regression with Numpy Multi-class Logistic Regression with Numpy A 2-layer Fully-Connected Neural Networks with Numpy Image Classification with Pytorch Style Transfer with VGG19 and Pytorch

You can find my solutions HERE

item.title: Supply Station
item.description: In Superpower Robot Team, I took the responsibility of the mechanical design of the supply station. My team participated in RoboMaster 2017, a robot tactical combat competition, and we won the second prize in Eastern China Sector. The supply station need to collect bullet balls from a “tube”, store them and distribute them to fellow robots. It serves as the foundation of the whole match and means a lot. Generally, it consist of 3 layers, which are collecting, storing and distributing layers from top to bottom. The supply station is a flexible platform, which I designed intentionally in case of any changes. It worked steadily during the competition in Eastern China Sector and efficiently supported the fight of my team. And in the qualifying games for National Competition, the regulations on supply station had a little modification, the number of bullet balls provided each in each game had been significantly increased. As a result, we could have enough bullets to load fellow robots several times! I designed a more efficient and robust triggering facility to adapt to that change. Besides, I reformed the collecting layer by adding a counting function, so that we could precisely distribute bullets to our fighters.

item.title: Online courses I've attended
item.description:
There are a lot of academic institutes and individual researchers offering free online courses and learning materials to everyone. I’m really grateful that I can learn what I’m interested in, and I’ve benefit a lot from them. I like to study courses on YouTube because it’s free of charge and has no limitation. I can conveniently get access to it almost anywhere with my smartphone. The online courses I’ve attended basically contains the following catagories: mathematics, programming and Robotics and Artificial Intelligence.

Mathematics

MIT 18.06 Linear Algebra

MIT actually offers a newer version of this course since 2018, along with the 6th edit of Prof. Strang’s book. But personally, I took the version of Fall 2011 I was quite moved by Prof. Strang’s devotion to teaching. In some lectures, there is no student in the classroom. And I learned from the comments that Prof. Strang re-recorded the video to improve something that he was not satisfied with.

MIT 6.042 Mathematics for Computer Science

This course talks about proof, tree, graph, counting and discrete probability. There is a free online text book on MIT OCW. It also talks about an example on random walk, which is quite similar to that in MIT 6.0002

Highlights of Calculus

Prof. Strang is really a devoted teacher!!!!! It is not a full course of calculus, I took it to review what I’ve learned in my college courses.

The Essence of Linear Algebra

This course is offered by 3Blue1Brown. In this series, he used vivid animation to illustrates matrix and the corresponding spatial transform, which is really inspiring and intuitively understandable. I actually started from this and went on to MIT 18.06

Programming

Official Python Tutorial

This is probably the best tutorial of python. It provides a comprehensive overview of python and explains how they works, which is often omitted by many textbooks. I read this along with the textbook of MIT 6.0001 & 6.0002

MIT 6.0001 & 6.0002

I like these wonderful series very much! They are really suitable for a novice who want to learn data science–me, for example. Notably, Prof. Grimson and Dr. Anna wears the same clothes through out 6.0001 and 6.0002 ^_^.

Robotics and AI

In recent years, robotics and AI have gone through remarkable progress. Many new ideas are proposed almost every day, and learning it is impossible to keep abreast of the trend only by courses in the classroom. Therefore, I have spontaneously taken several online courses to know the latest development of these amazing subjects.

CS229 Machine Learning

CS231N Convolutional Neural Networks for Visual Recognition

MIT 6.S191 Introduction to Deep Learning

MIT 6.S094 Deep Learning for Self-Driving Cars

PyTorchZeroToAll

Other Topics

Kalman Filter

Lagrange Multiplers Khan Academy
